368475: Faithless Looting.author: blurrymadness
368475: Faithless Looting.text_parsed:
Cards like this are card disadvantage, but they give card-quality advantage and allow you to run less lands in your deck. Drop this the turn you'd miss your land drop and you won't be unhappy. Also, drop those extra lands to this so you can keep playing the game.

Lord knows how many games I've lost to drawing an extra 3 lands when I needed something else..

368475: Faithless Looting.author: jerkoid
368475: Faithless Looting.text_parsed: This card works so damned well with Pyromancer Ascension. It just adds a ton of consistency and options for really cheap. lets you filter your hand and load up your graveyard with copies of spells to get Ascension online. To top it off, casting flashback spells will put a counter on Ascension if you have another copy of the spell in the graveyard as it resolves! Run with Think Twice and Desperate Ravings... and a lot of burn, of course.

368476: Ashmouth Hound.author: Ragebarbarian
368476: Ashmouth Hound.text_parsed:
Yes, it is slightly behind the 2/2 standard but that's because it combines well with lure or even madcap skills. Give it death touch and it becomes a possible board wipe to some or all of your opponents creatures.

If this duel deck had 4 copies of vexing devil and hellrider it would be just plain cruel. You have to realize that these are rare, and duel decks usually supply only one of the specific rare because multiple would either be broken for the cost of the duel deck or it would not flow right with the mana curve and every thing. Besides, this card can kill a vexing devil and/or a hellrider if it just attacks or block it. Not saying they would block it unless absolutely necessary, or they are sure that their creature will not die from the block. This card could warrant removal, but it is likely that it will die after one use. That is unless you equip artifacts giving it indestructibility or additional blocks and extra toughness. Even an enchantment that prevents combat damage it deals and is dealt to it could go well with it if it is equipped or enchanted with other cards.

Overall, it isn't that bad. This is what a common should be.

P.s. it looks more like an elemental cat rather than an elemental hound.

368479: Gatekeeper of Malakir.author: YuriLove333
368479: Gatekeeper of Malakir.text_parsed:
Combo him with the Mimic Vat in a creature removal deck.

If you're not into the sacrifice a creature type Vampire deck build just save a destroy spell and use it on the Gatekeeper to imprint on the Mimic Vat. It'll pay off each turn when you put a kicked Gatekeeper token onto the field and make you're opponent sacrifice somthing each turn.

Or if you're into the sacrifice a creature type Vampire cards put a chump like Viscera Seer or Bloodthrone Vampire in to stop oponents from gaining control of your stronger creatures and you could use either one to just sacrifice the Gatkeeper and then imprint him on the Mimic Vat for lots of fun each turn

Also goes great with a dash of Blood Artist.

That doesn't work. Just look at the reminder text for kicker:

Mimic Vat is does not cast the exiled card. It just puts a token copy onto the battlefield. Fleshbag Marauder and Mimic Vat would be a better pairing.

368483: Blightning.author: igniteice
368483: Blightning.text_parsed: Tibalt in the back hiding in the shadows with his creepy face is awesome, but the blightning effect on the face, pouring out of his fingers, pales in comparison to the cynical touch of the original art. That bleak dark skull with smoke and lightning etching out of it epitomized the cruelty of hitting for a solid 3 for 3 CMC and then punishing them further with two discards. This art makes Blightning look like Mini-Blightning, as if it's doing only 2 damage and 1 discard.

368483: Blightning.author: Mode
368483: Blightning.text_parsed:
(Art comparison rant)

While the old artwork seemed to be more focused on the black aspect with the "memory loss",
this new artwork is more focused on the burn from the red aspect.

In my opinion, the old one was already somewhat iconic and is easily distinguishable from other cards,
which is probably the reason why most people tend to prefer that one.

But the new one is just as great:
It seems the memory loss is induced here by the severe pain from melting that poor guy's freaking face!
And you still see that the burns aren't caused by flames but by lightning, so it's still true to the card's name.
Also, we get to see Tibalt enjoying what he does best - which i think is forcefully sharing his madness with others.

368485: Lingering Souls.author: EGarrett01
368485: Lingering Souls.text_parsed:
I'm sure I'll get voted down for this...this card is or was obviously very strong in standard, but people keep putting it in Legacy decks and it's honestly not good enough.

You can watch tons of MTGO games on Youtube. In every single one of them, (no literally EVERY SINGLE ONE), Lingering Souls does nothing but put out some overcosted 1/1 tokens that put little-to-no pressure on the opponent or end up chump blocking en route to a loss.

Take Lingering Souls out of your Legacy decks.

368486: Breaking Point.author: Tayren
368486: Breaking Point.text_parsed:
Always loved the "Punisher" spells, and especially in this deck, where they are very flavorful for Tibalt.
They get a lot of hate for giving your opponent choices, but if played right, none of them should be good choices for him. Breaking Point especially has two options for you opponent: A way undercosted burn, or a slightly undercosted board wipe. No matter what he chooses, this card is a lot of value for 3 mana.

368490: Bump in the Night.author: DarthParallax
368490: Bump in the Night.text_parsed:
I don't like hard-to-use Flashback costs. I REALLY don't like them. :/ You want to play Past in Flames if you use this.

Also, this was the first Black/x vs. Black/x Duel Deck, and they failed to put in Doom Blades and good Black creatures in both decks for the lolz.

I don't know whether I'm proud of Wizards for resisting the temptation, or annoyed that the ironic chance of actually not being able to cast Doom Blade because the thing you want to kill is Black will now probably never happen, anywhere. Considering that all the instance where it would matter, the deck using Doom Blade probably has something else like a Counterspell for the Black creatures..

Or one of like 3 common Black instants that hit Black creatures. (Go For the Throat, Victim of Night, and Ultimate Price)

368490: Bump in the Night.author: SAUS3
368490: Bump in the Night.text_parsed:
I really like this card. The flavour is actually awesome.

There's a bump in the night and it hurts you. It's not the end of the world, but it still hurts. Since it stays in the graveyard, it kind of haunts the player "when will it come again?" in a similar way you would feel if you had a night terror or something.

As for power, I really like it as well. I have it as a 2-of in my modern peasant deck (5-colour burn deck) as a way to keep my opponent worrying. It's a nice way to close a game by dropping something like 2 or 3 burn spells on 1 turn to finish them off, or as a flashback mini-burn to get rid of that last 2 or 3 life.

Look at it as more of a lava axe variant where it is much more useful in the early game, but can still have that over-costed, but valuable damage later in the game.

368491: Terminate.author: SevesDariku
368491: Terminate.text_parsed:
This card is solid. It does not obsolete Murder (Hero's Downfall did that), Terror, or Doom Blade. In case you forgot, you have to have two colors to put this in your deck.

Red and black are the two most destructive colors in magic, particularly at destroying creatures, and particularly for minimal mana cost. (White has creature removal, but aside from the early-early stuff like Swords to Plowshares, white pays a premium for the privilege)

So... a 2CMC red/black removal spell that just plain works?
Yeah, that seems fair to me.


... Pity I almost never play red. I'll stick with Doom Blade for now.

The reason I think it is black and white is because in the fight between Gerrard and Urza are fighting, Urza is somewhat corrupted by Yawgmoth (I think), perverting his original paragon of justice self against the Phyrexians, making him lose his sanity and turn to dark magic to win the favor of Yawgmoth and slay Gerrard. The original art shows it way better.

368495: Death Grasp.author: djflo
368495: Death Grasp.text_parsed:
I like this card so much for the simple fact that unlike Corrupt, Consume Spirit, and any other variable creature/player drain effects, this doesn't force you into all black.

Cards like Ribbons of Night do a decent job but aren't quite the finisher this is; Exsanguinate and Debt to the Deathless are both very strong but lack the versatility of this card.

368496: Fiend Hunter.author: Ragebarbarian
368496: Fiend Hunter.text_parsed: It may be considered worse than oblivion ring or even path to nowhere, but it is a 1/3 creature.  This  card was probably meant to be flickered with soulshift, conjurer's closet, etc.  It gets rid of a single creature and gets you a creature that can block or attack.  Sure, it dies to removal spells like doom blade or lightning bolt, but it gets rid of a removal and/or a creature.  Realize that they could have blocked with this creature and  you can swing in with one less creature to worry about.  It is basically two spells in one.

368496: Fiend Hunter.author: kronos1225
368496: Fiend Hunter.text_parsed:
what do you think of this combo?
cast a champion of the parish then cast a fiend hunter and target an opposing creature,then a second fiend hunter and exile the first one (returning the opposing creature).then a third fiend hunter and exile your second one,return your first and exile the third return the second and exile the first..... this way the champion of parish can get infinite +1/+1 counters.or if you cant stop this loop(because there is no creature on your opponents battlefield) just end the duel with a Draw. some tutoring is required to make it work.
368496: Fiend Hunter.text_posted:
what do you think of this combo?
cast a [autocard]champion of the parish[/autocard] then cast a [autocard]fiend hunter[/autocard] and target an opposing creature,then a second fiend hunter and exile the first one (returning the opposing creature).then a third fiend hunter and exile your second one,return your first and exile the third return the second and exile the first..... this way the champion of parish can get infinite +1/+1 counters.or if you cant stop this loop(because there is no creature on your opponents battlefield) just end the duel with a Draw.  some tutoring is required to make it work.[autocard][/autocard]

368498: Mortify.author: FlashCaster
368498: Mortify.text_parsed:
This card is so damn good it's scary.

This is easily in the top 10 targeted removals in Magic, and it even rivals the likes of Vindicate since this is an instant. Since they both have the same exact mana cost they are a good comparison and a study of the importance of instant speed.

In the end this is actually better due to the speed but Vindicate is just cooler, more versatile, and super iconic which makes me like it more just as a card. Speed is also why Terminate edges out Dreadbore in the end as well.

Putrefy is ever so slightly better than this since it hits artifacts instead which is often more useful in my opinion.

Mortify/Putrefy 4.5/5
Vindicate 5/5
Terminate 5/5
Dreadbore 4.5/5

368501: Butcher of Malakir.author: OnyxSturm
368501: Butcher of Malakir.text_parsed:
Easily 5/5. Some people compare him negatively with Grave Pact but he's actually better based on the fact that he doesn't force your teammate to sacrifice.

His rather large mana cost of 7 makes it pretty difficult to hard-cast him, which is why I always cheat him out with the Buried Alive/Exhume combo along with Disciple of Griselbrand and Reassembling Skeleton.

Bring the Disciple out with any return spell and you've got a pretty efficient sac/lifegain machine that, with enough mana, gets rid of any hexproof/indestructable/protection from colors anyone has. Combos nicely with a lot of things, especially Dark Prophecy and Tragic Slip.

368503: Doomed Traveler.author: DarthParallax
368503: Doomed Traveler.text_parsed:
Sorin's deck is actually nice though :) Honestly, Sorin has an ACTUALLY COMPELLING/DEVELOPED background story, so he is a complicated Noble Vampire Lord who is an advocate of Human Rights and a Blood Traitor. o.O He's got possibly the second-best story after Jace! (And Jace's loses a star of rating for overhype. :3)

This is honestly one of the most perfect cards to put in Sorin's Deck, since it makes a Spirit token, meaning you've got TWO tribes represented here: the Humans Sorin cares about, and the Spirits that are easy to mechanically support with his deck. And besides, you know you just want that flying creature anyway. Intangible Virtue is a card I strongly recommend adding to the deck, but would have made it too powerful for Tibalt to beat, lol.

This is bugging me, is the grammar wrong here in the flavor text? Surely the 'doesn't' ought to be a 'didn't'?

The 'Doesn't' means he currently don't know about it, and the 'was' means that he was right. Which translate into he is now dead, but became a spirit which has no recollection of his original life except that he will not rest until he reaches his destination.

368505: Evolving Wilds.author: Traius
368505: Evolving Wilds.text_parsed:
This card is really over-rated. Terramorphic expanse's 3.75 stars is a lot closer to right. The best thing that you can say about this card is, at least you cut 2 lands at the same time from your deck (making it slightly less likely to draw another land). Dual lands also come into play tapped (and sometimes don't!), and should achieve the same "choice of mana" function for 2-3 colour decks. I guess 5 colour decks might find dual lands insufficient, but then chromatic lantern is almost certainly more useful than this card.

For perspective, the original dual lands are only ~.6 stars higher than this rating, on average.

368506: Decompose.author: DarthParallax
368506: Decompose.text_parsed:
Counter target Buried Alive, and target deck while you're at it.

yeah...Kryptnyt..umm..I SUPPOSE all Spikes will do that, of course. But Vorthos does rather prefer this card for having very appropriate art. :P And people that are "Anti-Spikes"- who kind of enjoy low-tech cards and sort of want to sometimes make decks that try to play as Alpha-y as possible...they should probably stick with the Decomposes actually :)

It's not overpowered. It's even got room for more pushing and still be uncommon. But it's an elegant Designed card. I like Elegant Designs so much, like glasses of water, that I would sometimes take them over way over-priced wine, since even though the wine is better, over-pricing is far too inelegant to appreciate as much as simple clean water. :P

Shred Memory isn't exactly hard to get but...it's fancy mechanically, and REALLY, who NEEDS this effect at Instant speed? Unless the opponent is Dredge or something idiotically OP like that, in which case anything that costs more cards, tempo, or mana than Tormod's Crypt and is less destructive than Relic of Progenitus is far too slow-weak. And I like to try to talk up cards whenever possible, like Evan Erwin and MaRo, so that is how I'm 'selling' Decompose. More 'Core' than Shred Memory. For whatever that is worth to people. :)

368507: Blazing Salvo.author: blurrymadness
368507: Blazing Salvo.text_parsed:
Always run next to other burn. This either becomes Lightning bolt 5-8 or it grants tremendous tempo advantage in a burn deck. It's weakest attribute is that it requires an opponent's creature to cast it on, meaning it is occasionally a dead card. I love casting it on 4 toughness creatures when other burn is at the ready, because even though it's card disadvantage, it is often enough to threaten their win con and they'll eat 5.

Also runs well with Vexing Devil simply because one devil, bolt, salvo = 60% of their health. Probably run near staggershock. 5 of those in any combination will ruin an opponent by t3-t4. No god draws. Just 5 non-lands and 3 lands.

368507: Blazing Salvo.author: Paleopaladin
368507: Blazing Salvo.text_parsed:
I'll say it again and again for people who like to hate "punisher" cards and trot out the "Your opponent will always pick what's better for them!" line:

Your opponent won't always KNOW what's better for them. They (usually) don't know exactly what's in your hand, in the rest of your library, and (most importantly) what you've got planned for them in your head.

Also, lots of players (even the sharpest cats in competitive play) will sometimes make an irrational choice.

YES, you *DO* need to build around a punisher strategy a bit.

YES, Blazing Salvo is not an auto 4-of in every burn deck.

I really hope this gets reprinted in some set that will be legal in modern.

368510: Field of Souls.author: leomistico
368510: Field of Souls.text_parsed:
This is one of the reasons why I hate some of the new wordings.
Battlefield - why such a long word? Field wasn't enought? If one of the problem about templating is that shorter and cleaner is better, why use such a convoluted and cacophonic word? Moreover, in Italian it translated to "campo di battaglia", that can be really long and daunting to read at first sight.

Play/cast - I like "cast" (I've started during Tempest era, so I was used to it), but why a land can only be played and not casted? This brings some other annoying wordings, like the one on Intet: "why it says 'play that card', instead of 'cast that card'?" is a logical question. This wording is not consistent...

Die - As we can see on this card, is another inconsistent word. It only refers to creatures that you control and own that goes to your own graveyard. It doesn't refer to: creatures that you don't own, creatures that you don't control, non-creature permanents. Althought some of them are only corner-cases, you have to be comprehensive in the text box: if you aren't, cards can be misinterpreted. If you uses a non-consistent wording, you mislead players...

My propose: "battlefield" can simply become "field", but this is only a minor problem, so it can stay. Use "cast" to land and spells. Get rid of "die": people would uses it nontheless, but at least you can be comprehensive and consistent. Or use die for everything...

On the other hand, I like "exile"...

368511: Torrent of Souls.author: blurrymadness
368511: Torrent of Souls.text_parsed:
Notably; one of the few (only?) reanimations that:
-Grants haste
-Without sacrificing/exiling your creature later
-Gets to still choose any creature in your graveyard

That makes this prime reanimation if you're not running super-beasts like Reanimate or Exhume. In multiplayer this is actually preferable to either of the above! You can still do it T3 too.

T1 - Discard outlet (putrid imp)
T2 - Some creature you like..
T3 - Pitch The Defiler, evoke Shriekmaw, sac shriekmaw on the stack to Burnt Offering, cast this with that mana

You could do something similar with Shallow Grave making it a 2-card "combo", but this is useful all game, so if you don't land a vicious combo like the above, you get to simply cast it later like a normal game. Makes any black or red fatty a 5-mana fat instead; which is awesome.

You can perform the above combo on T2 with Ingot Chewer as well.

368514: Unmake.author: Enelysios
368514: Unmake.text_parsed:
I love the art, but its so very specific to shadowmoor that I wish they would change it up. Still, this is an amazing card. Great no questions asked removal. Not quite up at the level of Vindicate or Swords to Plowshares but still way above the curve.

I am still not sure why they decided to print the hybrid costed cards at a power level equivalent to spells that require two colors. Most of the time its an advantage, allowing white or black decks to play it and offering supreme flexibility to Orzhov decks. The only time you pay for that flexibility is against creatures with protection.

368518: Devil's Play.author: DarthParallax
368518: Devil's Play.text_parsed:
Doaj, it's not that bad. And people will be very happy that some of these cards were Innistrad-picks for Flavor (Hellrider, you are the flaming, hasty, ass-kicking elephant in the room right now).

Since BOTH Planeswalkers are from Innistrad, it actually makes sense from the same 'Worldbuilding' perspective that makes them put way more time into Basic Lands than anyone who doesn't read R&D Articles would think is ever possible. I mean come on BASIC LANDS? But it's true.

They wanted this Duel Deck to feel like it's being fought on Innistrad. That *was* the right direction. I only question some things on a card-by-card logic though, since there were a few places where better things could have been chosen. Random Orzhov ghost in Sorin's deck feels like a flavor foul for some reason. Is it just because it's a Black-White card with the Spirit type?

Sorin's Deck should have had High Ground, for reasons that become obvious when you compare the box art to High Ground's comment thread B| >.< :D

Seriously go click and look that card up, then buy four of them, then put the proxy art you KNOW it deserves onto it! :D

368523: Akoum Refuge.author: leomistico
368523: Akoum Refuge.text_parsed:
I like this cycle of land! Even if only 1 life is almost nothing, it can gain a turn, sometimes: often I lose (or win) with just the exact amount of damages, so in some cases it can help a little...

But what upset me is that they always do only the friend-color pair. Hope to see more equality in the future...

And another cycle of land that I would really love to see is something like this:
~ enters the field tapped.
When ~ enters the field, add to your mana pool.
: Add or to your mana pool.
and its siblings... In this way, you don't get the specific mana the turn that you cast it, but you don't lose tempo in the late game. And at the beginning you could cast a one mana artifact, like a Spellbomb or a Sensei's Divining Top.

4.5/5

368527: Absorb Vis.author: Ultimario
368527: Absorb Vis.text_parsed:
The point of this card is the versatility. Early game you basic landcycle it to grab a Plains if you don't have one, or ensure you can cast Vampire Nighthawk or Spectral Procession asap. You're not playing green, so 2 mana to fetch whatever land you want isn't too bad. A manafixing artifact or investing in better lands would be better options than running this, but still. Also, late game this buys you some time / knocks their life total down so that you can kill them with fliers even if their creatures are overall a bit better.

It's still a pretty bad card, but it's not terrible.

368528: Browbeat.author: igniteice
368528: Browbeat.text_parsed:
Love the new art. The old art did have a nice 'back alley' type of look to it, which fit the theme of the card beautifully, but this new art screams pain. "Give me my cards or suffer!" Unfortunately, I'd almost always rather have three cards. It's kind of like casting Dash Hopes. You're probably going to use it against a spell you really want to counter, and they're probably just going to take the five damage, which leaves you saying, "Well, I guess them taking five damage is better than nothing." Otherwise, if you use Dash Hopes against some spell they don't care about, they let it counter, and now you've just done a 1 for 1, but you'd rather have had them take the five damage.

Here just as well, I can't imagine anyone saying, "I sure hope they take the five damage so I don't draw my next three burn spells."

368528: Browbeat.author: SAUS3
368528: Browbeat.text_parsed:
This card is meant for really fast, aggressive decks. Use this as a finisher, or a nice starter. Early game, it's a lava axe for 3 mana. Late game, they choose to take a lava axe, or risk giving you 3 more burn spells which will probably total to even more damage.

Opponent chooses is usually a major drawback to a card. To make up for it, the card should do a lot more for its cost. This card does that well. A red draw spell that is better than divination? That would be stupid. Lava axe at 3 mana? That would also be stupid. Opponent chooses? Okay it's fair now. This card is good.

368528: Browbeat.author: blurrymadness
368528: Browbeat.text_parsed:
Oddly enough I think drawing 3 cards is typically weaker here. They *may* draw 2 burn spells, but more than likely they'll have to wait a turn to use them. If you can manipulate the draw (black or blue) then you have a better chance of knowing what to pick.

Giving a burn deck 5 damage is not something you want to do; giving it cards at least gives you a chance to live (unless they have 5 mountains, in which they just burn you anyway.)

Better for them to have to use more mana and cards for burn than to just give it up to them. Think about it. Same with vexing devil; use a bounce or kill spell on it. Don't let that burn deck hit your life total!

368528: Browbeat.author: Mazakur
368528: Browbeat.text_parsed:
I have this card in a black/red deck, but I think that I might switch it into my Izzet deck. If I can combo it with Melek, Izzet Paragon and a Guttersnipe on the field, you get to cast it twice, doing 2 damage per cast with Guttersnipe. If your opponent doesn't want you to draw, he takes 14 damage. At best he takes 4 damage and you draw six. If you have a Chandra, the Firebrand on the field you could copy it again, for 6 damage from a single Guttersnipe, and any combination of draw 9 cards/do 5 damage draw 6/do 10 damage draw 3/or do a grand total of 21 damage.

It's a win/win. Either do 5 damage for 3 mana (compare to lava axe for 5 dmg for 5 mana) or draw 3 for 3 mana (in a burn deck) while most draw 3's have a CMC of 4.

368528: Browbeat.author: Lamaboy4
368528: Browbeat.text_parsed:
I play red/black control.
To play control you need some cards in your hand, but sometimes you have cards and you just want to kill an opponent. People say that your opponents get the choice, which is technically true, but you can easily influence them to the pick the option you want.

Want to draw three cards? Get them around or below 10 life and they will not want to take the damage, so attack first, then cast this.

Want to deal damage? Save your damage spells and attack after you cast this.

Works nicely with traitorous instinct because they won't be expecting the damage from their own creatures (if you have enough mana).

Great card, never feels useless. 5/5
368528: Browbeat.text_posted:
I play red/black control.
To play control you need some cards in your hand, but sometimes you have cards and you just want to kill an opponent. People say that your opponents get the choice, which is technically true, but you can easily influence them to the pick the option you want.

Want to draw three cards? Get them around or below 10 life and they will not want to take the damage, so attack first, then cast this.

Want to deal damage? Save your damage spells and attack after you cast this.

Works nicely with [autocard]traitorous instinct[/autocard] because they won't be expecting the damage from their own creatures (if you have enough mana).

Great card, never feels useless. 5/5

368528: Browbeat.author: Paleopaladin
368528: Browbeat.text_parsed:
These "punisher" cards (Vexing Devil,Temporal Extortion,Dash Hopes, this) are amazing "skill testers." Some n00bs will see the powerful effects and think they're auto-includes (they're not). Some net-decker twits will think they don't work at all because they aren't common sights in top 8s.

What I will say is this: these cards can be circumstantially amazing. You have to put some thought into the rest of your deck, yes, but these cards will reqard you if you design properly for them.

Believe it or not, they work pretty well together too!

368528: Browbeat.author: Gummibears
368528: Browbeat.text_parsed:
Browbeat really is disappointing. I see a lot of people across the "punisher" themed cards' comment sections arguing for their effectiveness by pointing out that each mode is heavily undercosted, but that comparison is irrelevant. You're not getting the mode you want, you're getting the mode you don't want, and whoever thinks that's irrelevant should consider the cases when you're playing the card. Most people here seem to like this card for a straight burn/RDW, so let's entertain some possibilities.

Example 1: You're against a control player who has four cards in hand by turn 3. You have three cards in hand, this, a Skullcrack, and a Lightning Bolt, and three mountains in play. Let's say they've got a creature on the board that's giving you grief, e.g. a Meddling Mage, and you want it gone. Your opponent has two islands open. You would have to tap out to play the Browbeat, and there's no chance of sneaking it in at the end of their turn since it's a sorcery. Obviously any card can be countered, but getting a sorcery that costs all of your mana shut down leaves you completely flat-footed for your opponent's turn. It loses you both tempo and card advantage. You either sit on the Browbeat hoping for your opponent to tap out so you can play it on a future turn and play your other two cards with your open mana, or you chance the Browbeat into a potential (and highly likely) counter. Even if you do resolve it, your opponent will probably take the damage, draw up to five, and be ready to deal with the burn you throw at them next with whatever they've been developing over the past three turns. You don't want to give a control player too many options, control is all about creating a situation that favors them. You have to assume they will know the situation that best favors them and will twist it to their advantage given enough time. Browbeat will give them, if nothing else, time because of its sorcery speed awkwardness and relatively high cost for a burn spell. This is just one case where I'd much rather have a Flames of the Blood Hand, a Magma Jet, or a Arc Trail.

Example 2: You're playing against zoo with a fully developed board and it's turn 5. You have four mountains open. You're facing down ten power of creatures at less than ten life. They have four life. You topdeck a Browbeat, play it, and they let you draw three cards. You don't draw anything that can deal four damage for one mana. They proceed to kill you with their creatures and the burn in their hand. This is one case where you'd much rather have that four damage out of a Flame Javelin.

I could give you more examples and more matchups, but these two examples highlight my main problems with the card. It's inflexible, it's awkward, and it always gives you what you want less. You have to assume your opponent is intelligent and knows what mode will benefit their deck more at the time you play it. I'd like to like Browbeat, it's a flavorful and interesting card, but ultimately it's not a particularly good one. If you want to play a "punisher" themed card in a burn, Vexing Devil is much better.

368530: Hellrider.author: SAUS3
368530: Hellrider.text_parsed:
@Darksythe222
It's not worthless if your opponent board wipes. That's the thing about haste. They don't get a blocker out until you've swung at least once.

In the type of deck this guy was meant for, you don't need to worry about board wipes anyway. You play fast, small creatures and a ton of burn spells. If your opponent hopes to stop you with a board wipe, they will most likely lose to the volley of burn spells that they no longer have mana to counter.

If your opponent plays something like increasing devotion with the intention of mass chump blocking all day, they will still take a ton of damage.

Picture it as a massive raid to the face every time you attack. On top of that, you get a 3/3 with haste. It's awesome.

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: ChttrBox88
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
Tibalt, The Fiend-Blooded, ah one of my favorite thematic planeswalkers, decked out in new super awesome art and looking better then ever.

And yet, he is by far the Worst Planeswalker ever created. In no deck is he useful, and even in casual decks he has to compete with commons that are more then capable of doing his job better.

Compared to his rival Sorin, Lord of Innistrad, he is a joke. Sorin comes down and can immediately drop down an emblem AND still have loyalty kicking around. If Tibalt wants to drop his -4 to do 0-5 damage, a lousy effect in comparison, he has to spend two on random looting AND kill himself in the process. Sorin can ult immediately after three turns of getting the benefits of his token, while Tibalt has to spend 4 turns on an ability that is a downside half the time before even getting to ultimate, and Tibalt has virtually no chance of getting use out of it.
Even counting the fact that Tibalt can come out two turns earlier, his -4 comes out the same turn that Sorin can -2, assuming Tibalt kills himself, and their ults come out at the same time either way.

Even given each ability on its own right he is so thoroughly inefficient.

His -6 is completely useless, the only time when it would be useful, where your opponent has an overwhelming creature base, is exactly the situation in which Tibalt won't survive. Even if you can keep your opponents creature base low, his ability in on-board. Nobody will willing play creatures just so you can steal them. And given how much time is takes to plus him up that high anyway, a hardcast Insurrection would probably be more useful.

His -4 is finicky at best. It takes two turns to get that magic number, and even longer if you want Tibalt to survive or you are under any pressure at all. The effectiveness is also completely questionable. Even in the best situation you won't be getting much more then 5 damage, and at worst it doesn't do anything at all (But to be honest Tibalt would not survive in that situation anyway). For two mana and three turns, Tibalt has a hard time competing with Thunderous Wrath or even Searing Spear in terms of strait up damage.

And that brings us to his +1 the bread and butter planeswalker ability which is the main reason that Tibalt will even be played, and it sucks horribly. If Hymm of Tourach has ever been a better example, random discard is SIGNIFICANTLY worse then regular discard. You are being forced to play a random guessing game with your best cards, with the best case scenario being you get a draw and card and discard a card looting effect that any given blue looter gets for the same mana. Even if you go all the way to build the best possible deck for him and make any given card in your hand able to be discardable (Like some Flayer of the Hatebound Unburial Rites reanimator) You are still paying two mana and two turns for something that is generally worse then Faithless Looting, a common from the set PRIOR.

Maybe Tibalt is good because he is better then the sum of his parts. I mean many planeswalkers like Chandra The Firebrand and suffer from weak individual abilities, but make up for them by having variety and synergy with themselves. This would be the case if Tibalt HAD and synergy with himself. All of his abilities have nothing in common with each other, and are all generally worse then the commons still in standard that he derives his abilities from. It just makes me mad the Tibalt is SO bad.

Fun Fact: Tibalt wil never actually grant you card advantage. :3
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_posted:
Tibalt, The Fiend-Blooded, ah one of my favorite thematic planeswalkers, decked out in new super awesome art and looking better then ever. 

And yet, he is by far the Worst Planeswalker ever created. In no deck is he useful, and even in casual decks he has to compete with commons that are more then capable of doing his job better. 

Compared to his rival [autocard]Sorin, Lord of Innistrad[/autocard], he is a joke. Sorin comes down and can immediately drop down an emblem AND still have loyalty kicking around. If Tibalt wants to drop his -4 to do 0-5 damage, a lousy effect in comparison, he has to spend two on random looting AND kill himself in the process. Sorin can ult immediately after three turns of getting the benefits of his token, while Tibalt has to spend 4 turns on an ability that is a downside half the time before even getting to ultimate, and Tibalt has virtually no chance of getting use out of it.
 Even counting the fact that Tibalt can come out two turns earlier, his -4 comes out the same turn that Sorin can -2, assuming Tibalt kills himself, and their ults come out at the same time either way. 

Even given each ability on its own right he is so thoroughly inefficient.

His -6 is completely useless, the only time when it would be useful, where your opponent has an overwhelming creature base, is exactly the situation in which Tibalt won't survive. Even if you can keep your opponents creature base low, his ability in on-board. Nobody will willing play creatures just so you can steal them. And given how much time is takes to plus him up that high anyway, a hardcast Insurrection would probably be more useful.

His -4 is finicky at best. It takes two turns to get that magic number, and even longer if you want Tibalt to survive or you are under any pressure at all. The effectiveness is also completely questionable. Even in the best situation you won't be getting much more then 5 damage, and at worst it doesn't do anything at all (But to be honest Tibalt would not survive in that situation anyway). For two mana and three turns, Tibalt has a hard time competing with [autocard]Thunderous Wrath[/autocard] or even [autocard]Searing Spear[/autocard] in terms of strait up damage.

And that brings us to his +1 the bread and butter planeswalker ability which is the main reason that Tibalt will even be played, and it sucks horribly. If Hymm of Tourach has ever been a better example, random discard is SIGNIFICANTLY worse then regular discard. You are being forced to play a random guessing game with your best cards, with the best case scenario being you get a draw and card and discard a card looting effect that any given blue looter gets for the same mana. Even if you go all the way to build the best possible deck for him and make any given card in your hand able to be discardable (Like some [autocard]Flayer of the Hatebound[/autocard] [autocard]Unburial Rites[/autocard] reanimator) You are still paying two mana and two turns for something that is generally worse then [autocard]Faithless Looting[/autocard], a common from the set PRIOR. 

Maybe Tibalt is good because he is better then the sum of his parts. I mean many planeswalkers like [autocard]Chandra The Firebrand[/autocard] and suffer from weak individual abilities, but make up for them by having variety and synergy with themselves. This would be the case if Tibalt HAD and synergy with himself. All of his abilities have nothing in common with each other, and are all generally worse then the commons still in standard that he derives his abilities from. It just makes me mad the Tibalt is SO bad.

Fun Fact: Tibalt wil never actually grant you card advantage. :3

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: Lwonders
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed: A lot of these comments are calling Tibalt useless and only good because of his art. Well he costs 2 to bring out so you get to start using him right away and that's good at the beginning of battles. Especially when the deck he is made for has so many effects that can be used from the graveyard. Put him out on your second turn (and odds are your opponent(s) can't hit him for another turn or so) draw your card, and with most of your cards activating in the graveyard the random card you're sending there is probably cheaper and more useful there then in your hand. You get to pretty much replace the card you want in the grave with something that you may be able to use right then. And if you keep adding cards with effects such as "deal # amount of damage to # amount of cards" (for a basic example) then you can keep him protected by picking off anything that might hit him, and if not all of them you can a) kill some but not all, b) weaken a few, or c) kill some and weaken the ones attacking. With his reputation of being (quote) "the weakest planes walker ever made" (unquote) you may have several players overlooking him because they don't see him as a major threat, thus allowing you to store the damaging cards for when needed. The beauty of this planeswalker are his own weaknesses being able to make opponents (sometimes) overlook him, and if that doesn't work you can use his effect to quickly pay for cheap flashbacks. His -4 ability should really be saved for after using his -6. Because hitting someone with the -4 will alert them that though small he can have a nasty bite sort of speak. With the right hand (that isn't too hard to get) you can take your opponents creatures, attack him directly, or destroy some if not all of his creatures. Then destroy every remaining one so they have nothing. The most useful part that I can't seem to help but see as perhaps one of the most useful effects of all planes walkers is he's cheap, small enough to overlook (at least for a while) and can be a huge help with flashbacks and other like effects while storing damage cards in your hand. In a personal opinion his +1 effect is his greatest power of the three. His rival Sorin (the one from the duel decks) costs one black, one white, and two colorless. Not as quick to get out. Sure once he comes out you can have your emblems and vampires. But Tibalt can easily hit Sorin with two 3/1 creatures with haste and a flashback cost of 2. Meaning he can easily destroy Sorin the moment he comes out. Relying on the planeswalker to fight makes them more of a target as where Tibalt is not a fighter. He is made to help the cards in your deck, and he does that very well. For a fighting planeswalker Tibalt isn't tooth and claw and fighting with him is pointless and he is the worst in that way. But smashing apart the opponent with a cheap army, that's where he has other planeswalkers beat. In the future I can see Tibalt becoming the new Jace and quickly gaining new forms and powers matching his self defense fighting style making him potentially on of the best planeswalkers ever invented. All in all with Tibalt the action happens everywhere but the field, it happens where the opponents have the hardest times defending against.

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
They should have made a new Tibalt. This one is beyond saving with new artwork or not. That +1 is just terrible.

@infernaldarkness: Hmm...
Tibalt Enraged RR (3 loyalty)
+1: Reveal the top card of your library. If it's red, put it into your hand.
-3: Target creature gains haste and gets +2/+0 until end of turn. Untap that creature.
-6: Target player gets an emblem with 'All damage dealt to you from red sources is doubled'.

Better? I made him completely unusable in non-mono red though and his duel deck is red-black... but I still think it would be better this way. It never makes sense to me when the duel deck doesn't correspond with the promo card's colours.
The +1 is conditional card draw (if the top card of your library is a land, you get nothing).
The -3 is still very useful.
The -6 isn't crazily overpowered but it does a hell of a lot.

16 Creatures

2x Sulfuric Vortex
1x Torrent of Souls
1x Zombie Infestation

23 Land
4x Rakdos Carnarium
11x Swamp
8x Mountain


I have been waiting for an excuse to build a "GraveBurn" deck for a while. Tibalt gave it to me. ^_^ Let's go stake that vamp and burn his corpse!!! >D
There is not very much from PDS: Lightning because I wanted to keep the flavor seeming right- but I feel like Vithian Stinger is the card that most embodies everything about this deck besides Browbeat, which is why I have 3 of each. You wanna use Lightning Bolts, V. Stinger gives Vorthos a Flavor Thumbs Up :) If you extend the deck to be more than 61 cards, you can put in a lot more from F&L. Use whatever Vithian Stinger would think is good. :)

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: Bahamuto
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
The more I think about this card the worse I think it is. It comes down to this, when is he useful?

So if I play him early in the game, I better be sure I have a blocker for him, or some 2/2 guy is going to just end him quickly. He MAY have 3 Life at that point but do I really want to discard a card at random early in the game?

If he comes out later in the game, ok so I can better control the card I'm discarding, but his middle ability will be near useless then. He will loose -4 life for maybe 3 damage? If this was a -1 ability or a -2 ability that would be much better. Heck even a 0 wouldn't be too broken.

Ok sure his -6 ability is good, but you better be sure to kill you opponent with that cause your opponent will get the creatures back.

Terrible

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: GhostCounselor
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
I've wanted to like the idea of a two drop planeswalker for a long time, but the fact is that he's not useful. I've tried to imagine scenarios where he might be useful, envisioning him somehow working in a Snapcaster deck where you are casting burn spells for free, but the whole fun of snapcaster is the ability to burn someone twice in one turn potentially. I've wanted to imagine him in a turbo rakdos black/red deck, but he doesn't fit there considering they're so creature heavy and none of Rakdos's current spells in standard have any flashback abilities. Really, he's not worth the time and effort to put him into a deck. Go with Sorin and reap the rewards in that regard.

However, what I do like about Tibalt is that like his red planeswalker brethren Koth and Chandra, I feel like they've really captured the essence of red mana better then the other colors in planeswalker form. While Chandra is the passion and fury of fire and Koth is representative if the power and force of heat and forge, Tibalt is representative of the uncontrollable and pain inflicting nature of fire and (potentially) red mana. He may not do things as awesome as Koth or Chandra, but in the representation regard, he is a success.

I've wanted to imagine him in a turbo rakdos black/red deck, but he doesn't fit there considering they're so creature heavy and none of Rakdos's current spells in standard have any flashback abilities. Really, he's not worth the time and effort to put him into a deck. Go with Sorin and reap the rewards in that regard.

However, what I do like about Tibalt is that like his red planeswalker brethren [autocard]Koth[/autocard] and [autocard]Chandra[/autocard], I feel like they've really captured the essence of red mana better then the other colors in planeswalker form. While Chandra is the passion and fury of fire and Koth is representative if the power and force of heat and forge, Tibalt is representative of the uncontrollable and pain inflicting nature of fire and (potentially) red mana. He may not do things as awesome as Koth or Chandra, but in the representation regard, he is a success.

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: MagicCritic
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
Very very odd planeswalker. Comes in T2, at a very early stage for 2 red. Risky +1, powerful and abusive ult that will probably never see play, and -4 that is good early on.
Tibalt get's too much bias feedback, he is worse than Koth, but in my solid opinion better than all the Chandras. Chandra the Firebrand is essentially useless, Chandra Ablaze is expensive and isn't soulfully mono red, since it comes in too late. And, Chandra Nalar, don't even get me started.

A 2 MANA PLANESWALKER. Please, this card must've been pushed. When my friend plays it as early as T2, I know I'm fucked. He draws 3 lightning bolts and flashbacks the cards he discards. So good in decks that abuse graveyard-returns. I usually have 6 or 5 cards in my hand by T4 playing my Lifegain Selesnya deck, easy 5-6 damage. Then he keeps bombarding me with burns.

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: GrimjawxRULES
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
Tibalt's ult is kind of contradictory with the rest of his abilities. In black/red you'll want to use removal to take care of your opponent's creatures because your creatures will generally be terrible at blocking. It stands to reason then, that if Tibalt ever hits his ult your opponent won't have any creatures out, because removal is your most efficient way of protecting him. Vice versa, if your opponent ever has enough creatures to make Tibalt's ult worth it, then he should be dead. My only explanation would be using his ult to deal the "final blow" to your opponent, either by giving all of your creatures haste or by stealing that single creature that your opponent just summoned. Stand-offs can happen, of course, but with black/red they're usually very rare, again, because your creatures are generally bad at blocking.
That's how I feel about Tibalt in the duel deck at any rate...

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: Toraka
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
After a friend pulled one of these from a few random AVC boosters he bought, I took the fun task of explaining to him why it's bad.

"See, his abilities don't really do anything."

"He's still a Planeswalker for two mana! And Act of Treason is cool!"

"For which you have to somehow protect him while building loyalty."

"Still, he sifts your deck and the burn is nice."

"Dude. At random."

"... Yeah, he's bad."

Oh how much two words can change a card. I would gladly have paid another mana more if he had 3 loyalty and didn't discard at random, or even 4 mana if he got a bit of a workover.
I suppose he's fine if you build around him, but Planeswalkers should feel like they're seriously impacting how the game is played. For two mana, there's just not much that they could do to help him suck less. In fact, Tibalt is probably best ignored to death, watching you pitch your best spells in exchange for lands, feeding him a bit of damage every now and again to keep him from his ultimate.

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: absreim
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
So far there hasn't been a deck that makes great use out of him, but I don't think he is nearly as bad as many people make him out to be.

Looting at random, while inferior to being able to choose what card to discard, is not as bad I people make it out to be. You are just as likely to discard a card you want as you are to discard you don't want. It is also very possible to influence the odds in your favor by timing your plays (e.g. using the ability before playing a land if your hand is heavy on land).

Overall, I think he is a solid card. He just needs the right home to be effective.
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_posted:
So far there hasn't been a deck that makes great use out of him, but I don't think he is nearly as bad as many people make him out to be.

Looting at random, while inferior to being able to choose what card to discard, is not as bad I people make it out to be. You are just as likely to discard a card you want as you are to discard you don't want. It is also very possible to influence the odds in your favor by timing your plays (e.g. using the ability before playing a land if your hand is heavy on land).

Overall, I think he is a solid card. He just needs the right home to be effective.

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: Stuflames
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
It is easily noted that Tibalt's +1 is situationally a hindrance as well as a boon. Even in decks that utilize the discard, graveyard, or have cheap low-cost spells that they dump easily its random nature will often have the chance of leaving the best plays of a turn unrealized. Thus, his following abilities could arguably be gained at a cheaper rate since to gain loyalty you can actually be paying a true "cost". For all his CMC speed he arguably doesn't do much for coming out so early. Unless all you need is his +1, he is actually a slow and vulnerable planeswalker when looking at his further abilities.

I find it interesting that this is the first time to my knowledge Wizards has explored the design in a planeswalker, even tentatively as here, where the planeswalker actually has a reasonable chance of punishing you for their loyalty. I wonder if they will explore this further? I could see a suicide-black demon (just one option) 'walker that has at least one ability to straight-up punish you (life loss, creature sacrifice would both be flavorful, in the latter case potentially useful as Tibalt's is) in exchange for a loyalty increase.

368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.author: OnyxSturm
368531: Tibalt, the Fiend-Blooded.text_parsed:
People (on both printings) are paying too much attention to his +1 more so than the rest of his abilities. Yes he makes you draw and discard at random - meaning you might get rid of something useful - but that's only if you're running him in a deck where it's impossible to return your spells back from the graveyard. In red/black, it's not that hard to find spells that do that.

His -4 is to me just a nifty add-on. Someone running a Spellbook/Venser's Journal/etc. draw deck? Well, sucks for them.

But his -6 is where he shines - taking control of every creature on the field is pretty damn good, especially in a multiplayer setting. I've won quite a few games by just taking everyone's field and swinging it against them because, after all, Tibalt sucks, right? Why swing at him when there's more important targets?

That being said once people realize he's pretty decent they target him pretty quick, and having just 3 loyalty counters to start with (if you use his +1 right away) means he's easy to get rid of. Still an easy 4.5/5 just because he breaks planeswalker stereotypes while managing not to break my wallet.

368535: Sorin, Lord of Innistrad.author: Ragebarbarian
368535: Sorin, Lord of Innistrad.text_parsed:
Like another comment I read on Nissa, Sorin's +1 ability creates tokens. Sure, they might not be that powerful, but they can often serve as chump blockers or even attackers, especially when you use his
-2 ability. The vampire tokens can protect Sorin while you prepare for his -2 or even his -6 ability. Don't forget that they will gain you life. with enough +1/+0 emblems, you can gain massive amounts of life and formidable attackers.

Sure the white/black combo might interfere with your deck building a bit, but this is why you have Orzhov. With extort, you can gain even more life and delay until his secondary or ultimate ability. If you are worried about blockers or hasted attackers, Blind Obedience might be good to put in the deck. Although, with his new colors, Vampire Nocturnus may not be the best pick to put in a Vampire deck anymore. Maybe a Moat or protection sphere to stall.

Great Planeswalker. Great art. I hope that Tibalt dies swiftly.
368535: Sorin, Lord of Innistrad.text_posted:
Like another comment I read on Nissa, Sorin's +1 ability creates tokens.  Sure, they might not be that powerful, but they can often serve as chump blockers or even attackers, especially when you use his
-2 ability.  The vampire tokens can protect Sorin while you prepare for his -2 or even his -6 ability.  Don't forget that they will gain you life.  with enough +1/+0 emblems, you can gain massive amounts of life and formidable attackers.

Sure the white/black combo might interfere with your deck building a bit, but this is why you have Orzhov.  With extort, you can gain even more life and delay until his secondary or ultimate ability.  If you are worried about blockers or hasted attackers, Blind Obedience might be good to put in the deck.  Although, with his new colors, Vampire Nocturnus may not be the best pick to put in a Vampire deck anymore.  Maybe a Moat or protection sphere to stall.

Great Planeswalker.  Great art.  I hope that Tibalt dies swiftly.

368535: Sorin, Lord of Innistrad.author: GhostCounselor
368535: Sorin, Lord of Innistrad.text_parsed:
I haven't played with many planeswalkers, but this is far and away my favorite one that I've played with. I run a more aggro version of Orzhov in standard (using cards like Vampire Nighthawk, Frontline Medic, etc.), and I usually just get the emblem out right from the moment I cast him and don't bother with the vampire token ability. If he lives the next turn, then I'll start making vampires.

He's incredibly efficient and causes massive headaches for opponents. The resources they will devote to get rid of him a turn or two after he's played will make a lot of people kick themselves, wishing they had saved them for another time. Admittedly, I've never got to use his ultimate ability, but I have to admit it sounds fun. A must have card for any black/white deck in standard or modern, and he'll kick a lot of ass.

368535: Sorin, Lord of Innistrad.author: Khazpar
368535: Sorin, Lord of Innistrad.text_parsed:
@MynameisDakkon
Short answer: yes. If his last ability is activated and it targets at least one permanent you control, you may counter it with Not of This World. 368536: Flame Slash.author: Lamaboy4
368536: Flame Slash.text_parsed:
Well the only question is: "is it better that lightning bolt?"
The answer depends on your deck and play style. I tend to lightning bolt creatures rather than players and for that reason,
I might put one of these in my deck.

I did some research and these are the results:
flame slash can hit about 6000 out of 7015 existing creatures.
lightning bolt can hit about 5100 out of 7015 existing creatures.
That means this card can hit about 900 more creatures than lightning bolt. That makes this card 1/6 or 16.7% better at removing creatures!

This seems to make up for its inability to hit players, especially if, like me, you often remove creatures instead of dealing direct damage to players. I give this card 5/5.

368536: Flame Slash.author: Salient
368536: Flame Slash.text_parsed:
After receiving a reminder of Zendikar's fiery temper and dislike of strangers, the Eldrazi remembered they have double-digit toughness and stomped face unabated.

It was so, so, so, so funny to see someone Top 8 a Legacy tournament with a monored Burn deck packing four of these. Merfolk had just come back in a big way thanks to their new level-up-eriffic lord, but Flame Slash kept the fish down long enough to get a few more Goblin Guide attacks through FTW.

I guess in a sense it's the Coralhelm Commanders that actually had forgotten about Zendikar's fiery temper and dislike of strangers.

368536: Flame Slash.author: Aremath
368536: Flame Slash.text_parsed:
There's a lot of discussion in these comments about whether this is better than Lightning Bolt. The short answer: it isn't. Instant speed is so much more relevant than the 1 damage especially in formats like modern. You get to knock off enchantments, hold up counterspells, and eot snapcast it like nobody's business. Oh, and bolt hits players and planeswalkers, meaning you can either finish off a damaged opponent or get rid of liliana.

That doesn't make it a bad card, though. Getting 4 damage for 1 mana is impressive, and will kill most creatures you're likely to care about in an aggro deck. I give it 4/5.

368539: Gang of Devils.author: AshToMoutHound
368539: Gang of Devils.text_parsed:
The fact that humans die and suffer a lot in Innistrad is somewhat softened by the flavor texts of the block's cards. I just love the humorous tone in them, and while humor is present in older and newer sets too, Innistrad will probably remain as my favourite set because of its humor and the fact it was when I really got into Magic. Somehow the whole disposable humans-feel reminds me of blowing up your whole battalion of Lemmings just for the heck of it.

The card feels a bit expensive but captures the feel of devils well. I would love to find some use for this in some wicked casual deck.

368542: Zealous Persecution.author: Ferlord
368542: Zealous Persecution.text_parsed:
Right, Continue!

And then we could replace that stupid Warleader's Helix because it's so stupidly placed. WHY isn't Lightning Helix back? WotC is full of idiots and don't understand that we need MORE power-creep, not less.
Oh! What about Skull Rend? That pile of doodoo should've been Blightning. Blightning is a significantly better card, and because of that, I should get what I want.

Sarcasm aside, it's good that Wizards knows when not to print too many powerful things on one set. Remember, Orzhov in RtR isn't a token-based guild. Their creatures are primarily high-cost, low power/toughness guys with Extort. Since most of them are fat and lazy (see Massive Raid and Act of Treason), they aren't the type to fight with their hands. That's why they can only create a mediocre spell.

368549: Twilight Drover.author: Syrtees
368549: Twilight Drover.text_parsed: I played a token deck against my girlfriends life-gain deck once. She had an X/X Avatar Token from Ajani and I had this guy out. She gave it 2 spirit loops and a spirit link, so her life total would triple whenever it dealt damage. I would just systematically block for as many tokens as I had mana to generate new ones. Whenever she tried to win with Felidar Sovereign I would exile it, and whenever she tried with her chalice I would just destroy it. 3 hours later the game ended as a choice stalemate where she had 3,780 life and I had roughly 100 spirit tokens on the field. I will always remember that game.
